bestBHT.bht: This distorted form of worship is a parody, blasphemously ascribing praise to a figure representing the revival of paganism under Roman rule. The worship of this beast, symbolizing Emperor Nero, mimics the language and titles reserved for God, mocking the true reverence owed to the divine. This idolatrous worship is justified by brute force, reflecting the belief that might makes right. It is a tragic travesty, distorting the true nature of worship and deviating from the rightful adoration of God.

Henry Alford: These words are a sort of parody, in their blasphemy, on ascriptions of praise to God.
They represent the relapse into all the substantial blasphemies of paganism under the resuscitated Empire of Rome.
The retention of pagan titles and forms.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: a parody of the name 'Michael' meaning, 'Who is like unto God?'
Albert Barnes: Can anyone doubt that this was the case under papal Rome; that the power which was set up under that entire domination, civil and ecclesiastical, was such as Satan approved, and such as he sought to have established on the earth?
This was, in fact, ascribing honors to him which belonged only to God; and this was the manner in which that civil and secular power was regarded in the period here supposed to be referred to.

They thus attributed to him omnipotence - an attribute belonging only to God. This found a fulfillment in the honor shown to the civil authority which sustained the papacy; for the policy was to impress the public mind with the belief that that power was invincible.
Marvin Vincent: Who is like unto the beast? A parody on a similar ascription to God."
See Isaiah 40:18, Isaiah 40:25; Isaiah 46:5; Psalms 113:5; Micah 7:18; Jeremiah 49:19.
Philip Schaff: This verse contains a parody of the ascriptions of praise given to the true God in many passages of the Old Testament.
But there is not a tittle of evidence to prove that homage of this kind was paid even to the thought of the resuscitated tyrant.
As invariably happens when a tyrant dies, the sentiment of the masses underwent an immediate and profound revulsion.
Archibald T. Robertson: The beast is merely the tool of the devil for worship. Recall the fact that the devil even proposed that Jesus worship him. Emperor-worship, like all idolatry, was devil-worship. The same thing is true today about self-worship (humanism or any other form of it).
The worship of such a monster as Nero was indeed a travesty of the worship of God.
Worship of the devil and the devil's agent is justified purely on the ground of brute force. It is the doctrine of Nietzsche that might makes right.
John Gill: They worshipped the dragon... in the idols, images, angels, and saints departed.
Woe to them that worship this beast.
Who is able to make war with him?

With the retention of pagan titles and forms, this worship mocks the language that rightfully belongs to God, even going as far as to parody names associated with divinity. The worship of this beast, symbolizing the tyrant Nero, can be seen as the devil's tool in promoting idolatry and self-worship. This worship, justified by brute force, is a tragic perversion of the true worship of God.
